content: The "Fiscal Integrity through Transparency (FIT) Act of 2008" aims to constrain the growth of the federal government by amending Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. The FIT Act of 2008 amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to restrict budget growth based on allowable growth percentage tied to economic indicators like mean earnings, employee compensation, and GDP. The FIT Act of 2008 amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to restrict budget growth based on economic indicators. Waiver of subsection (a) requires a two-thirds vote in the House of Representatives or Senate. Title II of the FIT Act focuses on efficiency and responsibility in the federal government, including requiring annual reports from federal departments and agencies to the Government Accountability Office. Each Federal department and agency must submit an annual report to the Comptroller General on total operating costs, including details on waste, fraud, and abuse. The Comptroller General will randomly audit 10 percent of these reports. Intelligence departments and agencies must also report total operating costs and details on waste, fraud, and abuse to the Select Committee on Intelligence of the House of Representatives. The first reports under this section must be submitted within one year of the Act's enactment, focusing on waste, fraud, and abuse. SEC. 202. ANNUAL REPORT BY COMPTROLLER GENERAL. The Comptroller General will provide Congress with an annual report on reports from federal departments and agencies. The first report must be submitted within 18 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 203. PLAN FOR REDUCTION OF OPERATIONAL COSTS OF FEDERAL DEPARTMENTS AND AGENCIES. Each Federal department or agency must create a plan to reduce operational costs by 41.67 percent within one year of the Act's enactment. They must implement the plan within 10 years and submit annual progress reports to Congress. SEC. 204 requires the Secretary of the Treasury to include a statement on tax returns showing the total waste, fraud, and abuse by Federal departments. The Comptroller General will report this information annually. SEC. 301 focuses on providing transparency for earmarks. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a new section on earmark transparency. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a new section on earmark transparency. Sec. 317 requires all requests for earmarks to be posted on the Committee on Appropriations' website at least 14 days before marking up the measure, including the name of the requesting Member, cost, and justification. Earmarks are defined as congressional earmarks in the House and congressionally directed in the Senate. The Senate defines a 'congressionally directed spending item' as per rule XLIV of its Standing Rules.
